Name: washington_dc_2005_astpt
Originator: DC Fire and Emergency Medical Services
OriginatorSort: DC Fire and Emergency Medical Services
Abstract:
This dataset represent the location of SARA Title III Hazardous Material locations (above ground) in Washington, DC 2005

A dataset listing provided by DC FEMS identified above ground Hazardous Material locations.   The dataset provides and standardized address generated during geocoding as well as the original source address information.  In addition, attibute information also includes points of contact information for each site listing

    <descript>
      <abstract>This dataset represent the location of SARA Title III Hazardous Material locations (above ground) in Washington, DC 2005

A dataset listing provided by DC FEMS identified above ground Hazardous Material locations.   The dataset provides and standardized address generated during geocoding as well as the original source address information.  In addition, attibute information also includes points of contact information for each site listing</abstract>
      <purpose>This data is used for the planning and management of Washington, D.C. by local government agencies.</purpose>
      <supplinf>In 1986, Congress passed the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA) as a response to the chemical accident that occurred in Bhopal, India in 1984. This was the incident in which a toxic gas, methyl isocyanate, escaped from an industrial plant and killed or injured 2,000 - 5,000 people. Title III of SARA, also known as the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act, establishes the public's right to know what chemicals are stored in their
communities. It also requires state and local governments to establish local committees to identify hazardous materials and to plan for responding to  reeases of the materials.

The Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) of 1986 lso known as SARA Title III, brings industry, government and the general public together to address emergency planning for accidental chemical releases. The emergency planning aspect requires communities to prepare for hazardous chemical releases through emergency planning. This provides essential information for emergency responders and creates a database of hazardous chemical storage information for the community. The community right-to-know aspect increases public awareness of chemical hazards in their community and allows the public and local governments to obtain information about these chemical hazards.</supplinf>
    </descript>

  <dataqual>
    <attracc>
      <attraccr>Data believed to be complete and accurate, subject to change. Not validated by source and/or responsible agency.</attraccr>
    </attracc>
    <logic>In process of validation by source and/or responsible agency.</logic>
    <complete>Data believed to be complete and accurate, subject to change. 

Much of the original address information was incorrectly entered and had to be altered in the Standardized Addresses in order to match with a location.  The standardized addresses were further altered slightly to match with a location near by.  Examples of these situations include: missing street type, misspelling of Massachusetts, and Brookley Ave containing Zeros in Left/Right Address fields.  

All original data entry was maintained for reference in the output shapefile.</complete>
    <posacc>
      <horizpa>
        <horizpar>Most points geocoded to MAR which are placed at the approximate center of building polygons.  Others are geocoded to the center lines while the remainder are manually placed using the planimetrics and 2002 orthophoto as a guide.</horizpar>
      </horizpa>
      <vertacc>
        <vertaccr>A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable </vertaccr>
      </vertacc>
    </posacc>

      <procstep>
        <procdesc>Dataset copied form the CD obtained from Washington, DC 2005

The raw data was provided in a standard table in a Microsoft Word document.  In order to properly bring the data into ArcGIS and geocode, first the data was copied into a Microsoft Excel Sheet.  A simple copy/paste function of the data was insufficient and required added organization of the data.  Added organization included removing previous formats and concatenating cells.

Once complete, the next step was to save the Excel Sheet as a DBF table and bring the data into ArcGIS, where a "US One Address" address locator (using Master Address Repository) was used to geocoded the data.  Any unmatched addresses were then geocoded against the District's Street Center Line Inventory.

Much of the original address information was incorrectly entered and had to be altered in the Standardized Addresses in order to match with a location.  The standardized addresses were further altered slightly to match with a location near by.  Examples of these situations include: missing street type, misspelling of Massachusetts, and Brookley Ave containing Zeros in Left/Right Address fields.  

All original data entry was maintained for reference in the output shapefile.</procdesc>
        <procdate>2005</procdate>
